awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Autonomous Wind and Solar Powered Cargo Vessels
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop autonomous, ocean-going cargo vessels powered by a combination of wind and solar power. These vessels will enable the provision of cheaper and more frequent sea freight service to isolated communities, such as those in coastal Alaska. The technology seeks to the lower operating costs by removing liquid or solid fuels or onboard crew, enabling the vessels to be more readily right-sized to particular routes and markets. The project may also have positive impacts on the environment by eliminating fossil fuel emissions and reducing marine noise impacts on wildlife, such as marine mammals.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will integrate existing robotic and energy capture technologies with newly developed wind/solar combined energy optimization software and autonomous contingency management. A vessel using both the wind and sun for propulsion has a difficult energy optimization problem, both on a minute-to-minute basis but also on the scale of an entire voyage; This project will build a model for solving this intermitancy problem given specific vessel performance characteristics and weather predictions. Likewise, this project will build a framework for addressing the autonomous contingency management problem for uncrewed marine surface vehicles given a particular set of vehicle and system characteristics. The focus will be on ship-to-shore communications contingencies because those are the most serious for the contemplated target system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to develop automated cargo ships powered by the wind and sun. Maritime transport emits approximately a billion tons CO2 equivalent of greenhouse gasses ever year. It is also widely considered to be a difficult sector to ameliorate due to the long distances involved. However, the wind and sun provide adequate energy supplies to replace fossil fuels in propelling ocean going ships. Sailing vessels were the only way to cross oceans up until the middle of the 19th century, and remained competitive up until rising labor rates in the aftermath of WWI rendered them uneconomical. Many vessels of the last generation of sailing freighters (built 1890-1926) were as fast or faster than current container vessels when they had favorable winds.

Automating the sailing process, as we aim to do, enables the reduction of crews to no more than that required for motor vessels of similar size. Modern weather forecasting and routing software enable modern sailing vessels to effectively choose its own wind under most circumstances, meaning that they can maintain schedule performance under a wider variety of conditions. Finally, our inclusion of solar powers actuators and hotel loads, as well as enabling electric propulsion for harbor operations and motoring past unfavorable winds.

During our Phase I, we modified an existing Hobie 16 sailing catamaran with our technology (pictured) and sailed it in Puget Sound. It uses a pair of wing sails with slotted flaps and flexible solar panels to simulate the power generated by skinning the wings in solar panels. During our test program, we were able to demonstrate the following performance metrics:

  • Successful controlled sailing on a given compass course.
  • Boat speed over ground equal to wind speed at low wind speeds.
  • Confirmed that solar power output exceeded predictions on the water. We hypothesized beforehand that light reflected off the water would increase solar output, and that appears to have been confirmed.

During Phase II, we anticipate modifying our wings to support testing at higher wind speeds and with some modifications that we believe will allow us to deliver better aerodynamic performance. Once that is complete, we will scale up to a wing size appropriate for propelling a small cargo or passenger vessel in commercial service.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Pierce Nichols

Image
  • Prototype vessel departing Shilshole Bay Marina in Seattle WA
    Otto Logger
    Copyrighted
    Pierce Nichols
    Prototype under sail
